programming.title: Object-Oriented Programming
programming.definition: A programming model that organizes code into objects with properties and methods.
programming.example: In Python, a class is an example of object-oriented programming.

programming.title: Algorithms
programming.definition: A set of ordered steps that solve a problem.
programming.example: An algorithm to sort a list of numbers.

programming.title: Function
programming.definition: A block of code that performs a specific task and can be reused.
programming.example: A function in Python that adds two numbers: def suma(a, b): return a + b

programming.title: Compilers
programming.definition: Programs that translate source code into machine-readable language.
programming.example: GCC is a compiler for the C programming language.

programming.title: Testing
programming.definition: The process of verifying that a program works correctly.
programming.example: Writing unit tests in Python using unittest.

programming.title: Variables
programming.definition: Containers for storing data to be used during program execution.

programming.title: Design Patterns
programming.definition: Reusable solutions to common problems in software development.
programming.example: The Singleton pattern ensures only one instance of a class exists.

programming.title: Logic
programming.definition: A set of rules used to make decisions in code.
programming.example: Using conditionals like if/else in programming.

programming.title: Frameworks
programming.definition: Sets of tools that facilitate software development.
programming.example: Django is a framework for building web applications in Python.

programming.title: Version Control
programming.definition: A system that tracks changes to source code over time.
programming.example: Git allows code version management and team collaboration.

data_analysis.title: Structured Data
data_analysis.definition: Data organized in tables with rows and columns, like in a spreadsheet.
data_analysis.example: An SQL database contains structured data.

data_analysis.title: Unstructured Data
data_analysis.definition: Data without a fixed format, such as free text, images, or videos.
data_analysis.example: A collection of emails is an example of unstructured data.

data_analysis.title: Data Cleaning
data_analysis.definition: The process of correcting or removing incorrect or duplicate data.
data_analysis.example: Removing empty values or typos from an Excel table.

data_analysis.title: Predictive Models
data_analysis.definition: Statistical models that predict future outcomes based on historical data.
data_analysis.example: A model that predicts whether a customer will make a purchase.

data_analysis.title: Transformation
data_analysis.definition: Changing the format or structure of data to improve analysis.
data_analysis.example: Converting date text into a standard format.

data_analysis.title: Data Visualization
data_analysis.definition: Representing data using charts to make it easier to understand.
data_analysis.example: A bar chart showing monthly sales.

data_analysis.title: Big Data
data_analysis.definition: Large and complex datasets that require new technologies for analysis.
data_analysis.example: Real-time analysis of social media data.

data_analysis.title: Database
data_analysis.definition: A system for efficiently storing, organizing, and accessing data.
data_analysis.example: MySQL, PostgreSQL, and MongoDB are examples of databases.

data_analysis.title: Data Warehouse
data_analysis.definition: A system that stores large amounts of historical data for analysis.
data_analysis.example: Used by companies to generate reports from different departments.

data_analysis.title: Data
data_analysis.definition: Raw information that has not yet been processed or interpreted.
data_analysis.example: A CSV file with names and ages is a data set.

artificial_intelligence.title: Machine Learning
artificial_intelligence.definition: A technique that allows computers to learn from data.
artificial_intelligence.example: A system that learns to recognize cat images.

artificial_intelligence.title: Artificial Neural Networks
artificial_intelligence.definition: Models inspired by the human brain that recognize complex patterns.
artificial_intelligence.example: Networks used for facial recognition in photos.

artificial_intelligence.title: Genetic Algorithms
artificial_intelligence.definition: An optimization method inspired by natural evolution.
artificial_intelligence.example: Solving mazes using natural selection and mutation.

artificial_intelligence.title: Intelligent Agents
artificial_intelligence.definition: Programs that perceive their environment and make decisions to achieve goals.
artificial_intelligence.example: A robot that follows a black line on the floor.

artificial_intelligence.title: Large Language Models
artificial_intelligence.definition: AI models trained on large amounts of text to generate natural language.
artificial_intelligence.example: ChatGPT is an example of an LLM.

artificial_intelligence.title: AI Bias
artificial_intelligence.definition: When AI models produce unfair results due to biased training data.
artificial_intelligence.example: A hiring system that favors a specific gender.

artificial_intelligence.title: Anomaly Detection
artificial_intelligence.definition: Identifying unusual or unexpected patterns in data.

artificial_intelligence.title: Tokenization
artificial_intelligence.definition: Splitting text into small parts called tokens for analysis.
artificial_intelligence.example: Breaking a sentence into individual words.

artificial_intelligence.title: Deepfakes
artificial_intelligence.definition: AI-generated fake videos that appear to be real.
artificial_intelligence.example: A video showing someone saying something they never actually said.

artificial_intelligence.title: Robotics
artificial_intelligence.definition: A field of technology that designs and builds robots.
artificial_intelligence.example: A robotic arm that assembles parts in a factory.

cloud_computing.title: Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS)
cloud_computing.definition: Provision of computing resources such as servers and networks over the internet.
cloud_computing.example: Amazon EC2 allows renting virtual servers.

cloud_computing.title: Platform as a Service (PaaS)
cloud_computing.definition: A complete environment for developing applications without managing the infrastructure.
cloud_computing.example: Google App Engine lets you build apps without worrying about servers.

cloud_computing.title: Private Cloud
cloud_computing.definition: Cloud infrastructure used exclusively by one organization.
cloud_computing.example: A university uses its own cloud to store academic data.

cloud_computing.title: Public Cloud
cloud_computing.definition: Cloud services provided by third-party vendors to the general public.
cloud_computing.example: Google Cloud, AWS, or Microsoft Azure.

cloud_computing.title: Virtualization
cloud_computing.definition: Creating virtual versions of physical resources like servers or operating systems.
cloud_computing.example: Running multiple operating systems on a single physical machine.

cloud_computing.title: Containers
cloud_computing.definition: Technology that packages applications and their dependencies into a single unit.
cloud_computing.example: Docker allows creating containers to run apps anywhere.

cloud_computing.title: Cloud Storage
cloud_computing.definition: Storing files and data on the internet instead of a local computer.

cloud_computing.title: Microservices
cloud_computing.definition: An architecture where applications are divided into small, independent services.
cloud_computing.example: Each part of an online store functions as a separate service.

cloud_computing.title: Bandwidth
cloud_computing.definition: The amount of data that can be transferred within a given time.
cloud_computing.example: A higher bandwidth connection loads videos faster.

cloud_computing.title: Data Center and CPU
cloud_computing.definition: Physical facilities that house servers and processors for cloud services.
cloud_computing.example: Amazon has data centers worldwide to provide its services.
